title: A future without doctors?
intro: Listen to the conversation and learn vocabulary along the way.
this_week_question: It’s a well-known fact that skin is the human body’s largest organ – but how much skin does the average adult have?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: the kind and caring behaviour shown by doctors and nurses to people who are ill
small brown or ginger spot on someone’s skin, especially a person with pale skin
a doctor’s judgement about what someone’s particular sickness or disease is, made after examining them
a useful and practical but approximate way of doing or measuring something

vocab.text: where, how, what, why on earth
vocab.desc: ...? an emphatic way of forming a statement or question to show frustration, anger, surprise or disbelief

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And I’m Sam.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Are you feeling well, Sam? No headache or sore throat?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: No, I feel fine thanks, Neil. Why do you ask?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I’ve been reading some inspirational stories about the doctors and nurses fighting Covid. When I was a boy, I always dreamed of becoming a doctor.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Ah, I see. Have you ever been in hospital?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, I have, and I remember the nurse’s bedside manner – you know, the kind and caring way that doctors and nurses treat people who are ill.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Nowadays more and more of the jobs that humans do are being carried out by machines. But I doubt that a doctor’s bedside manner could easily be replaced by a robot.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: In this programme, we’ll be discussing whether the revolution in artificial intelligence, often shortened to ‘AI’, could replace human doctors and nurses. We’ll be asking: can you imagine a future without doctors?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: In fact, machines are already doing some of the jobs traditionally done by doctors - scanning people’s bodies to detect skin cancer, for example.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, that’s true, Sam, and it links to my quiz question which is about human skin. It’s a well-known fact that skin is the human body’s largest organ – but how much skin does the average adult have? Is it: a) 2 square metres?, b) 3 square metres? or, c) 4 square metres?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Of course our skin gets loose as we age but I can’t believe there’s 3 square metres of it! I’ll say the answer is a) 2 square metres.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, we’ll find out if that’s correct later. Every year in the UK over 5 million people are treated for skin cancer. Catch it early and your chances of survival are increased.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Usually a skin specialist, or dermatologist, will examine your skin using a handheld microscope. But in 2017, a team of researchers at Stanford Medical School made an exciting announcement.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Here’s Oxford University researcher Daniel Susskind, telling BBC World Service programme, The Big Idea, what the medics at Stanford had invented:

transcript.author: Daniel Susskind
transcript.text: A team of researchers at Stamford last year announced the development of a system that, if you give it a photo of a freckle it can tell you as accurately as twenty-one leading dermatologists whether or not that freckle is cancerous .

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: The Stanford medical team had invented an AI system to analyse freckles – small brown spots found on people’s skin, especially on pale skin.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: As it turned out the AI programme was better than human doctors at telling whether a freckle was harmless or cancerous – connected to some type of cancer.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: So, it seems that artificial intelligence is already replacing humans when it comes to detecting cancer – and doing a better job of it.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But Daniel Susskind isn’t convinced. One reason is that AI systems still need humans to programme them – and as it turns out, knowing exactly how doctors detect illness remains something of a mystery.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Here’s Daniel Susskind again in conversation with BBC World Service programme, The Big Idea:

transcript.author: Daniel Susskind
transcript.text: If you ask a doctor how it is they make a diagnosis , they might be able to point you to particularly revealing parts of a reference book or give you a few rules of thumb , but ultimately they’d struggle… they’d say again it requires things like creativity and judgment, and these things are very difficult to articulate – and so traditionally it’s been thought very hard to automate – if a human being can’t explain how they do these special things, where on earth do we begin in writing instructions for a machine to follow?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Most doctors find it difficult to explain how they make a diagnosis – their judgement about what someone’s particular sickness is, made by examining them.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Diagnosing someone’s illness is complicated but there are some rules of thumb . A rule of thumb is a practical but approximate way of doing something.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: For example, when cooking, a good rule of thumb is two portions of water to one portion of rice.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Exactly. And because identifying sickness is so difficult, Daniel says “ where on earth do we begin writing instructions for a machine?” We use phrases like where, how or what on earth to show feelings like anger, surprise or disbelief.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I might show surprise by asking Sam, ‘ how on earth did you know the answer to that ?’

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Ha ha! I guess you’re talking about your quiz question, Neil? And you needn’t be so surprised – I’m naturally brainy!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Neil Of course you are. In my quiz question I asked Sam how much skin there is on an adult human body.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And I said it was a) 2 square metres.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Which was… the correct answer! With your brains I think you’d make a good doctor, Sam, and I’m sure you’d have a good bedside manner too.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: You mean, the kind and caring way that doctors and nurses treat their patients. OK, let’s recap the rest of the vocabulary, starting with freckle – a small brown spot on someone’s skin.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Freckles are usually harmless, but some skin spots can be cancerous – connected to cancer.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: A doctor’s diagnosis is their judgement about what someone’s particular sickness or disease is.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A rule of thumb is a useful but approximate way of doing or measuring something.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And finally, we use phrases like where on earth..? as a way to show emotions like anger, surprise or disbelief.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That’s all for this programme but join us for the next edition of 6 Minute English when we’ll discuss another trending topic and the related vocabulary.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Why on earth would you miss it? Goodbye for now!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Goodbye!

lines: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.
And I’m Sam.
Are you feeling well, Sam? No headache or sore throat?
No, I feel fine thanks, Neil. Why do you ask?
Well, I’ve been reading some inspirational stories about the doctors and nurses fighting Covid. When I was a boy, I always dreamed of becoming a doctor.
Ah, I see. Have you ever been in hospital?
Yes, I have, and I remember the nurse’s bedside manner – you know, the kind and caring way that doctors and nurses treat people who are ill.
Nowadays more and more of the jobs that humans do are being carried out by machines. But I doubt that a doctor’s bedside manner could easily be replaced by a robot.

In this programme, we’ll be discussing whether the revolution in artificial intelligence, often shortened to ‘AI’, could replace human doctors and nurses. We’ll be asking: can you imagine a future without doctors?
In fact, machines are already doing some of the jobs traditionally done by doctors - scanning people’s bodies to detect skin cancer, for example.

Yes, that’s true, Sam, and it links to my quiz question which is about human skin. It’s a well-known fact that skin is the human body’s largest organ – but how much skin does the average adult have? Is it: a) 2 square metres?, b) 3 square metres? or, c) 4 square metres?
Of course our skin gets loose as we age but I can’t believe there’s 3 square metres of it! I’ll say the answer is a) 2 square metres.
OK, we’ll find out if that’s correct later. Every year in the UK over 5 million people are treated for skin cancer. Catch it early and your chances of survival are increased.
Usually a skin specialist, or dermatologist, will examine your skin using a handheld microscope. But in 2017, a team of researchers at Stanford Medical School made an exciting announcement.
Here’s Oxford University researcher Daniel Susskind, telling BBC World Service programme, The Big Idea, what the medics at Stanford had invented:

A team of researchers at Stamford last year announced the development of a system that, if you give it a photo of a freckle it can tell you as accurately as twenty-one leading dermatologists whether or not that freckle is cancerous .
The Stanford medical team had invented an AI system to analyse freckles – small brown spots found on people’s skin, especially on pale skin.
As it turned out the AI programme was better than human doctors at telling whether a freckle was harmless or cancerous – connected to some type of cancer.
So, it seems that artificial intelligence is already replacing humans when it comes to detecting cancer – and doing a better job of it.

But Daniel Susskind isn’t convinced. One reason is that AI systems still need humans to programme them – and as it turns out, knowing exactly how doctors detect illness remains something of a mystery.
Here’s Daniel Susskind again in conversation with BBC World Service programme, The Big Idea:

If you ask a doctor how it is they make a diagnosis , they might be able to point you to particularly revealing parts of a reference book or give you a few rules of thumb , but ultimately they’d struggle… they’d say again it requires things like creativity and judgment, and these things are very difficult to articulate – and so traditionally it’s been thought very hard to automate – if a human being can’t explain how they do these special things, where on earth do we begin in writing instructions for a machine to follow?
Most doctors find it difficult to explain how they make a diagnosis – their judgement about what someone’s particular sickness is, made by examining them.
Diagnosing someone’s illness is complicated but there are some rules of thumb . A rule of thumb is a practical but approximate way of doing something.
For example, when cooking, a good rule of thumb is two portions of water to one portion of rice.

Exactly. And because identifying sickness is so difficult, Daniel says “ where on earth do we begin writing instructions for a machine?” We use phrases like where, how or what on earth to show feelings like anger, surprise or disbelief.
